content.text: Define acceleration
The mass of the ball is \(0.0075 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the resultant force acting on the ball when it is accelerating downwards at \(2.8 \text{m/s}^2\)
resultant force = .........
Describe what happens to the acceleration between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 0.040 \text{s}\)
Explain why this happens
By drawing a tangent on Fig. 1.2, determine a value for the acceleration of the ball at \(t = 0.010 \text{s}\)
acceleration = .........
[Total: 10]
As the ball falls, its speed \(v\) is recorded. Fig. 1.2 is the speed–time graph for the falling ball
A long tube contains oil. A small ball is held at rest at the surface of the oil. At time \(t = 0\), the ball is released and begins to fall vertically through the oil
Fig. 1.1 shows the ball falling through the oil
As the ball begins to fall through the oil, it accelerates
the speed at which trolley P moves to the left
speed of P = .........
the kinetic energy of trolley Q when it moves at \(0.36 \text{m / s}\)
kinetic energy of Q = .........
Calculate:
State the energy transfer that takes place as the spring expands
[Total: 8]
Fig. 2.1 shows two identical trolleys, P and Q, held at rest on a frictionless horizontal surface. A load is fixed to trolley P
There is a compressed spring between trolley P and trolley Q
The trolleys are released. As the spring expands, it pushes the trolleys apart
Trolley Q moves to the right at a constant speed of \(0.36 \text{m / s}\)
The mass of each trolley is \(1.2 \text{kg}\). The mass of the load on trolley P is \(1.5 \text{kg}\)
The spring has negligible mass
State one way in which the motion of the particles in ice differs from the motion of the particles in water
State the name of the thermal process that transfers energy from the water to the ice
Initially, there is \(0.34 \text{kg}\) of water in the beaker. The specific heat capacity of water is \(4200 \text{J} / (\text{kg} \circ \text{C})\)
Calculate the energy transferred from this water as its temperature decreases from \(28^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) to \(10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
energy transferred = .........
The temperature of the water near the ice decreases first
Explain how convection causes the temperature of all the water in the beaker to decrease
State what happens to the internal energy of the water as the temperature of the water decreases
Describe the change in terms of the energy of the particles
[Total: 9]
Energy is transferred from the water to the block of ice
Fig. 3.1 shows a small block of ice floating in a beaker of warm water
State what is meant by 'focal point'
A student using the magnifying glass sees a magnified image of an object
On Fig. 4.1, mark:
• a point X on the principal axis for a possible position of the object
• a point E for a possible position of the student's eye
Underline **two** words in the list that describe the image produced in **(a)(ii)**
Fig. 4.1 shows the lens of the magnifying glass, its two focal points, \(\mathsf{F}_1\) and \(\mathsf{F}_2\) , and its principal axis
The speed of light in air is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
Calculate the speed of light in the glass
State what happens to the wavelength of light as it passes into the lens
The refractive index of the glass used to make the lens is 1.5
Converging lenses are used in spectacles (glasses) to correct one problem with vision
State the name of the problem and explain how a converging lens is used to correct it. You may draw a diagram
name of problem:
[Total: 10]
The lens in a magnifying glass is a converging lens
Describe how a longitudinal wave differs from a transverse wave
State whether this seismic wave is a P-wave (primary) or an S-wave (secondary). Justify your choice
The wave represented in Fig. 5.1 has a wavelength of \(1.2 \times 10^{4} \text{m}\)
Calculate the actual distance between point J and point K
distance = .........
The wave in (ii) travels through the ground at a speed of \(4600 \text{m/s}\)
As the wave passes a certain point, the ground completes 5 oscillations
Calculate the time that it takes for the wave to pass. Show your working
Fig. 5.1 represents a seismic wave produced by an earthquake
State what is meant by 'electric field'
Draw on Fig. 6.1 to show the pattern and direction of the electric field produced by the charge on the sphere. Draw at least **four** lines.
The sphere is negatively charged
The charge on the sphere produces an electric field in the surroundings
State what happens in the wire as the sphere is discharged
It takes a time of \(0.14 \text{ns}\) for the sphere to discharge completely
Calculate the average current in the earthed wire as the sphere discharges
The magnitude of the charge on the sphere is \(3.5 \times 10^{-10} \text{C}\)
An earthed metal wire is touched against the surface of the sphere and the sphere is discharged
Fig. 6.1 shows an isolated metal sphere suspended by an insulating thread from the ceiling
Define the term electromotive force
Draw a circuit diagram that shows all the \(1.5\mathrm{V}\) cells connected to produce an e.m.f. of \(7.5\mathrm{V}\), the variable resistor and the \(30\Omega\) resistor
The resistance of the variable resistor can be varied from \(0\Omega\) to a maximum resistance of \(150\Omega\)
Using the axes in Fig. 7.1, draw a graph to show how the current in the circuit varies with the resistance of the variable resistor as it increases from \(0\Omega\) to \(150\Omega\)
Determine and label the value of the maximum current on the \(y\)-axis
Fig. 7.1
The battery is connected in series with a variable resistor and a \(30\Omega\) resistor. The battery is made using \(1.5\mathrm{V}\) cells
The electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a battery is 7.5V
Complete the equation for this decay
The \(\beta \)-emission of thallium-208 is accompanied by \(\gamma \)-emission from the nucleus
Explain why this \(\gamma \)-emission does **not** affect the numbers in the equation in **(a)**(i)
Suggest **one** reason why a nucleus of thallium-208 is unstable
Thallium-208 decays to an isotope of lead (Pb)
A sample of thallium-208 is placed in a thick lead container. Fig. 8.1 shows a narrow beam of \(\beta \)-particles and \(\gamma \)-radiation emerging from a small hole in one side of the container
The narrow beam enters a region where there is a magnetic field that is directed into the page
On Fig. 8.1:
draw a line **labelled** \(\beta\) to indicate the path of the \(\beta\)-particles in the magnetic field
• draw a line **labelled** \(\gamma\) to indicate the path of the \(\gamma\)-radiation in the magnetic field
[Total: 8]
The isotope thallium-208 ( \(^{208}_{81}\mathrm{TI}\) ) is radioactive. It decays by \(\beta\) -decay
State the three regions of the electromagnetic spectrum in which the Sun emits the most energy
Electromagnetic radiation from the Sun travels at a speed of \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). The radiation takes \(500 \text{s}\) to reach the Earth
Calculate the distance from the Sun to the Earth
distance = .........
Describe and explain what happens as an interstellar cloud of gas forms a protostar
Describe and explain what happens as a protostar becomes a stable star
[Total: 9]
Approximately 4.6 billion years ago, the Sun formed from an interstellar cloud of gas and became a stable star
The Sun is one of many billions of stars in the Milky Way. The Sun emits a very large quantity of energy as electromagnetic radiation
